DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Says He'll Mediate in Sudan
DOC.TEXT: Visiting President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt pledged his help Sunday in mediating a settlement of the civil war in southern Sudan. Mubarak, in an apparent attempt to make himself acceptable to the rebels, seemed to pour cold water on an attempt by his host, military ruler Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, to reactivate a 1976 defense treaty with Egypt. El-Bashir has asked Mubarak, as a friend of Sudan and chairman of the Organization of African Unity, to mediate a settlement of the war that is crippling this East African country's economy. However, the leader of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, Col. John Garang, has demanded the scrapping of Sudan's military agreements with Egypt and Libya as one condition for making peace. The former civilian prime minister, Sadek el-Mahdi, whom el-Bashir toppled in a coup on June 30, said the agreements were canceled. But El-Bashir told the official Sudan News Agency Saturday that Sudan and Egypt are ``consulting on the procedures to reactivate these agreements.'' Asked about the treaty Sunday, Mubarak, with el-Bashir standing by his side, said, ``Sudan and Egypt are one country, and they do not need defense agreements.'' Mubarak spoke to reporters at Khartoum airport after arriving for a one-day visit to celebrate the 34th anniversary of Sudan's independence. ``We have contacts with the Garang movement, and our relations with the north are strong,'' Mubarak said. ``We are doing our utmost to solve the problem.'' Fighting between the southern rebels and the government has escalated yiice peace talks in Kenya collapsed Dec. 5 after five days of negotiations. Former President Jimmy Carter acted as unofficial observer at those talks.
